title: Nuwave 9pc Cookware Set Healthy Duralon Blue Ceramic Nonstick Coated, Diamond Infused Scratch-Resistant, PFAS Free, Oven Safe, Induction Ready & Evenly Heats, Tempered Glass Lids & Stay-Cool Handle
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best pans I ever bought', 'author': 'Dingo 883', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Granted, I've set a low bar for quality cookware, but these are impressive. They not only look really good, their no-stick surface is the best I've owned. I did have a fried egg stick a tiny bit to it, but the only oil I had was from the bacon I had cooked and drained the grease from, and even then, a little prodding with a spatula moved it around without a problem. Anyone complaining about food sticking probably used a spray oil and ruined the material.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A Top-Tier Cookware Set!', 'author': 'BellaLovesAmazon', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This is a gorgeous, top of the line cookware set! It is so well made and so fancy, I feel like it needs to cost at least double than what its going for. I chose the Cool Grey set with the beautiful dark blue ceramic coating, and let me tell you, this set makes me feel like I'm a Michelin star chef, even though I certainly cannot cook like one!This cookware set comes with 9 pieces, 3 pots, a frying pan, a saucepan, and their corresponding lids. I was skeptical of their non-stick coating, but I seriously did not have to use any oil to cook my eggs with! It felt like some sort of sorcery...you always see eggs slide off of pans in the infomercials, but it rarely happens in real life on non-stick pans and using no oil, but here we are. These pans take quickly to the heat and it does feel like the heat distribution is very even. Usually the center of then pan is really hot and the edges not so much, which causes a lot of uneven cooking, but the frying pan is solid. It cooked my chicken evenly, as well as my hamburger patties.I definitely recommend using silicone or wooden cooking utensils on any sort of non-stick coated pots and pans because scratching them and chipping the coating is inevitable when using steel utensils. These pots and pans were very easy to clean up afterwards, there didn't seem to be much cooked-on residue that stayed on them, and they washed very easily. Always wait until your pots and pans cool down though, before washing them, because cooler water on hot metal pans will cause them to warp over time.This is a stellar set of cookware! They are worth the price and then some, honestly! I say you should replace your old and worn out cookware with this set if you can, or buy this as a lovely wedding or housewarming gift. They'll think you spent a fortune and be none the wiser, that's how beautiful this cookware looks, and how well they perform! 5 stars all around!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars pretty', 'author': 'Lindsey', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This was a gift for my niece, as she recently got her own apartment. Her first comment was that they were really pretty. She was really excited to use them, she likes to cook. The feedback she has given me is that they work very well and are easy to clean up. They are high quality cookware.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 22, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Quaslity Pan Set – With a 10-year Limited warranty!', 'author': 'JF', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The Nuwave 9pc Cookware Set exceeded my expectations, standing out in terms of sturdiness, craftsmanship, and overall quality. Upon unboxing, the pans immediately showcased superior construction compared to my previous set from another brand that I got from Costco. A large part of what drew me to this pan set when I was looking to replace my aging set was the Duralon Blue all-natural ceramic coating since it is devoid of harmful chemicals like PFAS, PTFE, PFOA, lead, and cadmium. I found this commitment to safety, coupled with the thorough third-party testing done by TÜV Rheinland impressive, highlighting Nuwave's dedication to providing a healthy cooking environment and cookware set.When it comes to testing nonstick prowess, I always turn to scrambled eggs. After seasoning the pans with a bit of oil, these pans aced the test. Fluffy, light eggs with zero sticking or burning, even without additional oil or butter. They've proven themselves with various foods and meals, demonstrating versatility in the kitchen.However, a quick note on heat conduction—these pans distribute heat efficiently. When cooking anything, especially eggs, I recommend turning the heat down once the pan is preheated to avoid any unwanted browning. Additionally, it is unnecessary to preheat these pans at a high temperature, in fact the manufacturers manual says that preheating of the pan should not exceed 300 degrees Fahrenheit. Surprisingly, while the base conducts heat effectively, the handles remain cool despite being metal and lacking additional covering. It's a thoughtful touch that enhances the overall cooking experience.One thing to keep in mind is the size of the frying pan that comes with this set—it's ideal for omelets or a single toasted cheese sandwich. If you're in need of a larger sized frying pan, you might want to explore Nuwave’s 12 pc set where the larger frying pan is included. Lastly, the 10-year warranty is a standout feature. Nuwave stands firmly behind their products, and that kind of assurance is hard to beat. Additionally, I like the fact that if you were to run into any issues this company has a phone number where you can talk with an actual real person. This cookware set is a winner in my kitchen!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 11, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Quality pots and pans', 'author': 'Divineambition', 'rating': 4, 'content': "Cooking is a breeze with these. No food sticks which is nice. Cleaning is easy as well. My only complaint is how hot the handles get. They are metal but I wasn't expecting them to get as hot as they did.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 19, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfectly versatile and a breeze to use', 'author': 'J Wallace', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I got this primarily for the various size sauce pans and of course the little pan is a nice bonus, too. While we have a fancy family sized frying pans that are used for family meals, our pots and sauce pan haven't been updated, so I was very happy to come across this set by Nuwave. The set is beautiful and well made out of box. Putting it to test, it cooked beautifully, but the proof came during clean-up time, when my usual recipe would stick to the bottom of the pot after the meal and I'd need to give it a soak and scrub for clean-up, the Nuwave set handled it with a soapy sponge and water. So I've donated my old set and now cooking exclusively with the Nuwave set. I also like the little frying pans for small personal meals. It's easier on my wrist than the full size one I own. Fantastic quality. Recommend.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 12, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars The BEST cookware set I've ever owned!", 'author': 'Christina H.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I am loving this Nuwave cookware set. The rustic copper color is so pretty and goes perfectly with our camp kitchen décor. They heat evenly, cook everything perfectly and clean up so easily. I love the deeper skillet, it is perfect for making dishes with sauces that a regular frying pan isn't able to hold. The blue diamond coating lets nothing stick to it, even melted cheese and is a breeze to clean up. I won't let the teens put these in the dishwasher, so they are all washed by hand and thats super easy as well. reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great Pots', 'author': 'CJ Hudson', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These pots are wonderful! They heat evenly, clean up nicely, and look great. I highly recommend them.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 9, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best cookware ever.', 'author': 'Mark Adler', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I've been using the pan set for years now, and these are no different. The best cookware I've used, ever. The heat is transferred very fast and evenly on my gas burners. Food cooks well and sticks only very lightly. Easy to scrape while stirring. They clean easily.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 9, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great pots', 'author': 'BK', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Excellent pots. These have now become my favorite pots to use. They don’t have any Teflon and the nonstick works very well. Easy clean up. A little pricey but worth it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 20, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars This was part of the 12-piece set I purchased.', 'author': 'Judy L.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This was part of the 12-piece set I purchased. I have looked at this cookware before and have seen a few advertisements on it. In the past, I hesitated trying it since, in most of the pictures and videos, it looks like it has a bumpy or rough interior. When I saw the 7-quart hybrid sauce pan, I decided I had to try it to replace a 7-quart Staub Dutch oven that I have. I was so impressed by this sauce pan, I decided to buy the 12-piece set of this cookware. This set was shipped in two boxes. One box include the 6-piece pot set with lids ( 2 and 3 quart pots and 8 quart stock pot), and the other box included the 6-piece frying pan set with lids (8, 10, and 12 inch frying pans with lids).I cook quite a lot and have quit a lot of cookware of various types and brands, including Staub, Le Creuset, cast iron, , Tramontina, carbon steel, Calphalon stainless steel, and Ninja Premium cookware. In most of these, I have complete, or almost complete, sets of every piece available in each type of cookware. Each of these has their pros and cons, and all are very non-stick aside from cast iron and carbon steel that must be well seasoned.Since this review is for the HexClad cookware, I will not get into the pros and cons of each type of cookware, but will compare the HexClad cookware to some of them and let you know why I prefer this cookware over some of the others.It should be noted that it is suggested to wash and season the cookware with vegetable oil before using. I used Crisco shortening which I also use on my cast iron pans. When I seasoned the pans, the oil was completely absorbed. After the initial seasoning, these pans should not need to be seasoned again even when cleaned with soap and water. title: HexClad Hybrid Nonstick 6-Piece Fry Pan Set, 8, 10 and 12-Inch Frying Pans with Tempered Glass Lids, Stay-Cool Handles, Dishwasher and Oven Safe, Induction Ready, Compatible with All Cooktops
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best pans', 'author': 'Jason', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These are by far the best pans I've ever owned. I use my 1-quart pot as often as I do my larger pots!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 28, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Hexcellent Culinary Magic', 'author': 'Riad B.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Prepare to be hex-cited, fellow food enthusiasts, because the Hexclad pan set is about to change your cooking game in ways you never hex-pected! (See what I did there? Sorry, couldn't resist.)When it comes to kitchen sorcery, this pan set is nothing short of magical. It's like having a cauldron straight out of Hogwarts, minus the bubbling potions and broomsticks, of course.Let's talk about the non-stick hexagonal surface, which is truly a kitchen wizard's dream. It's like the Teflon gods descended from the heavens and bestowed upon us a pan that makes food glide effortlessly like a graceful ballerina on ice. No more scrubbing and scraping stuck-on messes while muttering incantations under your breath.But wait, there's more! The Hexclad pan set also features a hybrid construction that combines the best of both stainless steel and non-stick materials. It's like having the strength of a dragon and the gentleness of a unicorn all in one pan. And did I mention that these pans are oven-safe too? That's right, you can conjure up a masterpiece on the stovetop and then effortlessly transfer it to the oven for the finishing touches.In conclusion, if you're looking to add a touch of culinary enchantment to your kitchen, the Hexclad pan set is the answer to your cooking prayers. Whether you're a seasoned chef or a beginner in the world of potions and recipes, these pans will have you casting spells of deliciousness with every dish you create. So wave your spatula like a wand, slip on your chef's hat, and prepare to unlock a realm of culinary magic that will leave your taste buds spellbound. Accio Hexclad pan set!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 13, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Quality is not cheap', 'author': 'Dennis Strapon Jr', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These pans are not for freshman college kids. They distribute heat extremely well when cooking which is one of the key things to look at inside of a good cooking skillet. Cleaning I personally add a bit of water to the pan and use a high heat silicon spatula to remove anything left after cooking. HexClad does say you can use metal utensils on them. Personally, I wouldn't recommend that one bit. Hexclad does give a lifetime warranty but not from minor scratches, so buyer beware. Yes, they are scratch resistant, NOT scratch proof.These are not your typical nonstick or stainless steel skillets. They are designed to work with the functionality of both styles of pans. You need to season these skillets prior to use. You do not season them like a normal seasoning of a cast iron for say, but inside the packaging or HexClads Website it will tell you how to season them.Overall, I am very pleased with this purchase!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 16, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The hype is real, but... it turns out you have to know how to cook', 'author': 'Karl Houseknecht', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'If I\'d only had YouTube to assist in my purchase decision, I\'d have never bought these pans. Everyone is a critic. Everyone complains the pans aren\'t non-stick. It also turns out that none of these people giving the pans terrible reviews seem to have the faintest idea how to cook in the first place.If you dump scrambled eggs into a dry non-stick pan of any make or model, they\'re going to stick. And probably burn. Every single YouTube review tries the "egg test" by putting an egg into a hot, dry pan and guess what happens? If you dump frozen ravioli into a dry non-stick pan, they aren\'t going to thaw, much less cook, and they\'ll have scorch marks. If you try to make fried rice in a non-stick wok but don\'t use a drop of oil, the rice is going to stick and burn. If I tune into your HexClad product review and you tell me that you had to go to the store to buy vegetable oil to season the pans because you don\'t normally use any in your cooking, I\'m going to turn that video right off.So here\'s the deal: Are HexClad non-stick pans? Yes. And also no. They are hybrid cookware. But they are unique hybrid cookware unlike any I\'ve owned or tried. Must you use some oil in your cooking? 100% yes. It\'s actually in the instruction sheet that comes with the pans. Also, it\'s proper technique. How else are you going to ensure proper heat transfer to the food? Again, think about what you\'re buying here: hybrid cookware. A hybrid of what? A hybrid of non-stick cookware, which, no matter the brand, still will require some kind of oil or fat to be properly non-stick, and of stainless steel cookware, which most definitely requires oil or fat to be non-stick.The bottom line on this whole "they aren\'t non-stick" nonsense is that they most certainly are. When you want them to be. When you use proper cooking techniques.Now, how did they work out for me? I\'m not a chef. I\'m a home cook. But I like to think I\'m an above average home cook. Two of my good friends are foodies. One of them actually is a chef. The other is a skilled home cook and recently purchased a set of HexClad, which he really likes. We often cook and eat together.First test, after following the seasoning instructions, was with the 12" pan. I made sichuan chicken using boneless, skinless chicken thighs. While skeptical at first, I heated the pan on medium low as instructed, thinking no way is this going to be hot enough. With a little oil in the pan once it came up to temperature (within 2 minutes at that), the chicken cooked and even browned. Developed a nice sear on the outside. Beautiful, gorgeous color. And yet, when turning the meat it released from the pan with zero resistance and no residue left stuck on the pan surface. Removing the chicken, I added a tbsp more oil and in went the peppers and onion. Again, a gorgeous result. Nice searing and no sticking. Added the meat back, added sauce, and the same meal I had prepared the night before in my quality non-stick skillet actually looked far more appetizing. And it was delicious. I dare say, even better due to the increased Maillard reaction over standard non-stick pans. Clean up entailed a wet sponge and a gentle wipe and rinse and it was clean. Nothing stuck. No discoloration. Soap and water finish.After enjoying my meal, I just had to know if the pans were going to pass the test that would make them a keeper for me: the French Omelette test. So I heated up the 10" pan, scrambled and seasoned three eggs, and threw a knob of butter into the pan. Medium low heat was plenty enough to get the job done. I worked quickly, keeping the eggs moving to avoid forming large curds. Once nearly set, I began rolling. The egg came away from the pan without a single stick, and without even the need to add more butter to release it as I would in my regular non-stick pans. Perfect, soft, yellow (not browned), creamy French Omelette. Clean up was a non-event. Aside from a bit of butter there wasn\'t anything for the soap, water, and sponge to remove. This test sealed the deal for me.I have other decent pans: All-Clad D3 12" and 10" pans, and three non-stick Oxo 8", 10", and 12" pans (top rated by America\'s Test Kitchen). The All-Clads can work okay, but they were mostly a disappointment. They take too long to heat up, the heat dissipates quickly when food is added, and they have cold spots around the outside where there isn\'t direct flame. The Oxo pans are actually pretty great, but they have rubber handles which can\'t go into the oven, and even medium heat just isn\'t hot enough. Not the pan\'s fault, but you\'ll never get a sear on a non-stick surface. My goal here was to have ONE set of pans that could get proper searing, could be used in the oven, and still have non-stick properties. I have achieved that goal with the HexClad pans. My All-Clad and Oxo pans will be gifted to someone. I have no need for them anymore.Handles: Nice, fat handles on the HexClad that don\'t turn in your hands or get hot. The worst thing about the All-Clad D3\'s are the handles. I have nearly dumped the contents of both pans when tossing as the handles rotated in my palm. They are the absolute worst. I absolutely LOVE the HexClad handles.Lids: Every HexClad pan came with a nice, glass lid that fits perfectly, and has a steam vent. All-Clad? Because my D3 set didn\'t come with lids initially, All-Clad doesn\'t and won\'t sell them separately. I called All-Clad when I got them and asked if they\'d sell me some lids and they basically told me to go pound sand. They were actually rude and dismissive.Heat distribution: As mentioned, the All-Clad D3\'s didn\'t evenly distribute the heat to the outsides of the pan surface that weren\'t directly over flame, nor did they keep the heat when food was added. Even cranking the flame up to high was never enough to get a good sear. Not so with the HexClad. I was sure that the warning to not heat them above medium had something to do with the non-stick surface (and it might), but it\'s just not necessary to go any higher. The outsides of the pan are just as hot as the middle and they sear so well, keeping their heat even as food is added. They perform almost like carbon steel or cast iron in this regard.Non-stick: Covered this, but it bears repeating that these actually are non-stick when used properly.Appearance: They\'re gorgeous, aren\'t they? My friend\'s set has no discoloration after several months of daily, hard use, and he\'s never had to use Barkeeper\'s Friend or any scouring. They are absolutely stunning under the LED cook lights of my hood. Prettier by far than the All-Clad.I\'ve ordered the 2, 3, and 8 QT pot set, which arrives tomorrow, and expect to be equally happy if these pans are any indication. I also have a 10" wok arriving next week for my near daily stir fries. At some point, I may also add a 1 QT pot and 7 QT deep saute.The bottom line is that these pans aren\'t going to miraculously make you cook better. But they WILL reward good technique with superior results. I was skeptical coming into this that I wouldn\'t like them nearly as much as what I already had but any hesitation is gone. The hype is real with this tech.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 16, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars This was part of the 12-piece set I ordered', 'author': 'Judy L.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This was part of the 12 piece set I ordered that was shipped in 2 boxes. I have looked at this cookware before and have seen a few advertisements on it. In the past, I hesitated trying it since, in most of the pictures and videos, it looks like it has a bumpy or rough interior. When I saw the 7-quart hybrid sauce pan, I decided I had to try it to replace a 7-quart Staub Dutch oven that I have. I was so impressed by this sauce pan, I decided to buy the 12-piece set of this cookware. This set was shipped in two boxes. One box include the 6-piece pot set with lids ( 2 and 3 quart pots and 8 quart stock pot), and the other box included the 6-piece frying pan set with lids (8, 10, and 12 inch frying pans with lids).I cook quite a lot and have quit a lot of cookware of various types and brands, including Staub, Le Creuset, cast iron, , Tramontina, carbon steel, Calphalon stainless steel, and Ninja Premium cookware. In most of these, I have complete, or almost complete, sets of every piece available in each type of cookware. Each of these has their pros and cons, and all are very non-stick aside from cast iron and carbon steel that must be well seasoned.Since this review is for the HexClad cookware, I will not get into the pros and cons of each type of cookware, but will compare the HexClad cookware to some of them and let you know why I prefer this cookware over some of the others.It should be noted that it is suggested to wash and season the cookware with vegetable oil before using. I used Crisco shortening which I also use on my cast iron pans. When I seasoned the pans, the oil was completely absorbed. After the initial seasoning, these pans should not need to be seasoned again even when cleaned with soap and water. Cast iron and carbon steel pans should be seasoned after every use.So, what do I like about this cookware as compared to the other cookware I have?1 - Cast iron, and enameled cast iron is very heavy and must be seasoned after every use to maintain it. This cookware does not required seasoning after it is done initially. Carbon steel is not as heavy, but must also be seasoned after every use.2 - Stainless steel cookware needs to be cleaned very time with Bar Keeper's Friend to keep it clean and shiny. The HexClad cookware does have stainless steel on the exterior, but is easier to keep looking shiny since cooking is not done on it. Wash and dry works.3 - Most of the cookware mentioned above can be relatively nonstick when used and seasoned properly and after learning how to use it. Stainless cookware can be more challenging since temperature and what you cook can be issues. Cast iron, carbon steel, and even enameled cookware depends on persistent seasoning after every use aside from the Ninja Premium cookware that maintains a nonstick, easy to clean surface as does the HexClad cookware. Other than Tramontina cookware, the nonstick surfaces of most are durable.4 - As for weight, the cast iron and enameled cast iron (Staub and Le Creuset) are the heaviest, carbon steel comes in second, and HexClad and Ninja are about the same.5- The warranty for HexClad is lifetime vs. the Ninja warranty that is 5-10 year depending on whether you register cookware on the Ninja website. For the HexClad cookware, you must save your purchase receipt.This is all of the differences I can think of for now. If I think of more, I will add them. reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great Pots', 'author': 'CJ Hudson', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These pots are wonderful! They heat evenly, clean up nicely, and look great. I have looked at this cookware before and have seen a few advertisements on it. In the past, I hesitated trying it since, in most of the pictures and videos, it looks like it has a bumpy or rough interior. When I saw the 7-quart hybrid sauce pan, I decided I had to try it to replace a 7-quart Staub Dutch oven that I have. I was so impressed by this sauce pan, I decided to buy the 12-piece set of this cookware. This set was shipped in two boxes. One box include the 6-piece pot set with lids ( 2 and 3 quart pots and 8 quart stock pot), and the other box included the 6-piece frying pan set with lids (8, 10, and 12 inch frying pans with lids).I cook quite a lot and have quit a lot of cookware of various types and brands, including Staub, Le Creuset, cast iron, , Tramontina, carbon steel, Calphalon stainless steel, and Ninja Premium cookware. In most of these, I have complete, or almost complete, sets of every piece available in each type of cookware. Each of these has their pros and cons, and all are very non-stick aside from cast iron and carbon steel that must be well seasoned.Since this review is for the HexClad cookware, I will not get into the pros and cons of each type of cookware, but will compare the HexClad cookware to some of them and let you know why I prefer this cookware over some of the others.It should be noted that it is suggested to wash and season the cookware with vegetable oil before using. I used Crisco shortening which I also use on my cast iron pans. When I seasoned the pans, the oil was completely absorbed. After the initial seasoning, these pans should not need to be seasoned again even when cleaned with soap and water. Cast iron and carbon steel pans should be seasoned after every use.So, what do I like about this cookware as compared to the other cookware I have?1 - Cast iron, and enameled cast iron is very heavy and must be seasoned after every use to maintain it. This cookware does not required seasoning after it is done initially. Carbon steel is not as heavy, but must also be seasoned after every use.2 - Stainless steel cookware needs to be cleaned very time with Bar Keeper's Friend to keep it clean and shiny. The HexClad cookware does have stainless steel on the exterior, but is easier to keep looking shiny since cooking is not done on it. Wash and dry works.3 - Most of the cookware mentioned above can be relatively nonstick when used and seasoned properly and after learning how to use it. Stainless cookware can be more challenging since temperature and what you cook can be issues. Cast iron, carbon steel, and even enameled cookware depends on persistent seasoning after every use aside from the Ninja Premium cookware that maintains a nonstick, easy to clean surface as does the HexClad cookware. Other than Tramontina cookware, the nonstick surfaces of most are durable.4 - As for weight, the cast iron and enameled cast iron (Staub and Le Creuset) are the heaviest, carbon steel comes in second, and HexClad and Ninja are about the same.5- The warranty for HexClad is lifetime vs. the Ninja warranty that is 5-10 year depending on whether you register cookware on the Ninja website. For the HexClad cookware, you must save your purchase receipt.This is all of the differences I can think of for now. If I think of more, I will add them. For now, I am impressed with the HexClad cookware, but I will not likely eliminate much of the cookware I already have. As mentioned previously, each has their own benefits. I may eventually decide to eliminate some of the heavier cookware as it is more difficult to use. I may also eliminate cookware that requires more maintenance.I will update this review if my opinion changes. I hope this review was helpful for you.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 12, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Really are worth the higher price so far.', 'author': 'Fuzms', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Lately I had been treating pans as almost disposable. Nonstick is also great.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Absolutely love my new pots', 'author': 'Tricia G', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Love my new HexClad hybrid pots! As my skillets (another brand) wear out in time, I am looking forward to building my collection of HexClad. Tonn', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These are some of the most beautiful pots I have ever had! To be fair, since I just received them today, I only rated heat distribution and durability with 4 stars because I can’t say anything yet regarding those points as I have not used them yet. They certainly are easy to wash, but I just washed them to get them prepped for seasoning before use. I also have the HexClad 5 qt. Covered Dutch Oven.They have a nice weight to them, but not as heavy as cast iron or LeCreuset pieces. They definitely arrive securely packed in their own boxes and each piece is covered with a nice cloth type storage bag. Ha! ha! UPS… you can’t beat this packaging up!I can’t wait to order all of the rest of the pieces I want! They are a bit expensive, but in the long run they will last for many years.I saw ONE review that said she thought they were a waste of money because she said the food stuck to her pan and she had a hard time cleaning it. Out of ALL the reviews I read, it was the only one who said anything negative. My opinion on that review is that she most likely didn’t follow directions when she received it and didn’t SEASON the pan first before using it; and so blamed the pan!I did not find a single flaw or scratch on any of the pieces I received. They have a beautiful shiny mirror like finish on the outside, and all the welds on the handles are strong and clean.I would highly recommend them! Stop thinking about it and just buy them! You won’t be disappointed!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 16, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Awesome', 'author': 'Ask N RN', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I bought the Pans and these pots. Everything the company says about their products is 100% true! I have a Glass Top Electric Stove, I cooked with these pots and pans between Low and 2. They cook even and heat even, so far the best pots and pans set I ever owned. I know they cost a lot, but let's look at that, 3 pans with lids cost me $70 each. I can spend $40 for a fiberware maybe with the lid and it's a pain to clean. I cooked with one of the pans and cleaned up in less then 1 minute.. Buy theses pots and pans! 🙂", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Everything they claim and more.', 'author': 'Kindle Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': "We've been using this cookware for several months now and haven't found anything we didn't like about the sets we bought.Handles actually remain cool on the skillets and sauce pans, the hexclad coating covers not just the interiors but also the bottoms and is incredibly easy to clean. Most residue simply wipes out and a bit of soap & water gets the rest. While we have managed to burn food to the bottom once or twice (When they say cook at lower temps, pay attention. I've never had any other cookware I can say that about, and no, this isn't our first set of big name cookware.Yes, the price is steep for these, but in our opinion, you are definitely getting what you're paying for.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The quality is Outstanding!', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These are the best pans I've ever owned. After using the nicely-weighted pots/pans for two months, I concur with the reviews below (e.g., very durable, very easy cleanup, very pleased) The equal heat distribution is also worth noting since it enables cooking on lower heat and NOT having to shift items around in the pan to avoid hot spots. I use my 1-quart pot as often as I do my larger pots!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 28, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Hexcellent Culinary Magic', 'author': 'Riad B.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Prepare to be hex-cited, fellow food enthusiasts, because the Hexclad pan set is about to change your cooking game in ways you never hex-pected! (See what I did there? Sorry, couldn't resist.)When it comes to kitchen sorcery, this pan set is nothing short of magical. From the moment you lay eyes on its sleek hexagonal design, you know you're in for a culinary adventure like no other. It's like having a cauldron straight out of Hogwarts, minus the bubbling potions and broomsticks, of course.Let's talk about the non-stick hexagonal surface, which is truly a kitchen wizard's dream. It's like the Teflon gods descended from the heavens and bestowed upon us a pan that makes food glide effortlessly like a graceful ballerina on ice. No more scrubbing and scraping stuck-on messes while muttering incantations under your breath.But wait, there's more! The Hexclad pan set also features a hybrid construction that combines the best of both stainless steel and non-stick materials. It's like having the strength of a dragon and the gentleness of a unicorn all in one pan. It heats up evenly, retains heat like a master spellcaster, and allows for precise temperature control.Now, let me tell you about the first time I cooked with these pans. As I gently sautéed some veggies, I couldn't help but feel a sense of culinary wizardry coursing through my veins. The food cooked to perfection, evenly browned and beautifully caramelized. I almost expected sparks to fly out of the pan, but alas, it seems the magic was contained within the hexagonal surface.The ergonomic handles are like the wands of comfort, offering a secure grip that won't leave your hands feeling like they've been subjected to a Petrificus Totalus spell. And did I mention that these pans are oven-safe too? That's right, you can conjure up a masterpiece on the stovetop and then effortlessly transfer it to the oven for the finishing touches.In conclusion, if you're looking to add a touch of culinary enchantment to your kitchen, the Hexclad pan set is the answer to your cooking prayers. Whether you're a seasoned chef or a beginner in the world of potions and recipes, these pans will have you casting spells of deliciousness with every dish you create. So wave your spatula like a wand, slip on your chef's hat, and prepare to unlock a realm of culinary magic that will leave your taste buds spellbound. Accio Hexclad pan set!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 13, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Quality is not cheap', 'author': 'Dennis Strapon Jr', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These pans are not for freshman college kids. These pans are for the serious home cook who truely enjoys the process of cooking and can appreciate perfection. These pans are so perfectly designed to deliver high performance, quality meals, with complete temperature control. Its amazing how little heat it takes for these pans to perform compared to literally every other pan Ive ever used. They are not cheap, and are not light, but the quality is second to none. Im a big Gordon Ramsay fan, but was a little leary about these pans, thinking he's just trying to make money, but after using them, he's the perfect spokesman for this product! Try them, you will only be disappointed you didnt buy them sooner!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 1, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Worth It and More', 'author': 'Jon M.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Personal Experience: These pans are awesome to cook in! They distribute heat extremely well when cooking which is one of the key things to look at inside of a good cooking skillet. Cleaning I personally add a bit of water to the pan and use a high heat silicon spatula to remove anything left after cooking. HexClad does say you can use metal utensils on them. Personally, I wouldn't recommend that one bit. Hexclad does give a lifetime warranty but not from minor scratches, so buyer beware. Yes, they are scratch resistant, NOT scratch proof.These are not your typical nonstick or stainless steel skillets. They are designed to work with the functionality of both styles of pans. You need to season these skillets prior to use. You do not season them like a normal seasoning of a cast iron for say, but inside the packaging or HexClads Website it will tell you how to season them.Overall, I am very pleased with this purchase!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 16, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The hype is real, but... it turns out you have to know how to cook', 'author': 'Karl Houseknecht', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'If I\'d only had YouTube to assist in my purchase decision, I\'d have never bought these pans. Everyone is a critic. Everyone complains the pans aren\'t non-stick. It also turns out that none of these people giving the pans terrible reviews seem to have the faintest idea how to cook in the first place.If you dump scrambled eggs into a dry non-stick pan of any make or model, they\'re going to stick. And probably burn. Every single YouTube review tries the "egg test" by putting an egg into a hot, dry pan and guess what happens? If you dump frozen ravioli into a dry non-stick pan, they aren\'t going to thaw, much less cook, and they\'ll have scorch marks. If you try to make fried rice in a non-stick wok but don\'t use a drop of oil, the rice is going to stick and burn. If I tune into your HexClad product review and you tell me that you had to go to the store to buy vegetable oil to season the pans because you don\'t normally use any in your cooking, I\'m going to turn that video right off.So here\'s the deal: Are HexClad non-stick pans? Yes. And also no. They are hybrid cookware. But they are unique hybrid cookware unlike any I\'ve owned or tried. Must you use some oil in your cooking? 100% yes. It\'s actually in the instruction sheet that comes with the pans. Also, it\'s proper technique. How else are you going to ensure proper heat transfer to the food? Again, think about what you\'re buying here: hybrid cookware. A hybrid of what? A hybrid of non-stick cookware, which, no matter the brand, still will require some kind of oil or fat to be properly non-stick, and of stainless steel cookware, which most definitely requires oil or fat to be non-stick.The bottom line on this whole "they aren\'t non-stick" nonsense is that they most certainly are. When you want them to be. When you use proper cooking techniques.Now, how did they work out for me? I\'m not a chef. I\'m a home cook. But I like to think I\'m an above average home cook. Two of my good friends are foodies. One of them actually is a chef. The other is a skilled home cook and recently purchased a set of HexClad, which he really likes. We often cook and eat together.First test, after following the seasoning instructions, was with the 12" pan. I made sichuan chicken using boneless, skinless chicken thighs. While skeptical at first, I heated the pan on medium low as instructed, thinking no way is this going to be hot enough. With a little oil in the pan once it came up to temperature (within 2 minutes at that), the chicken cooked and even browned. Developed a nice sear on the outside. Beautiful, gorgeous color. And yet, when turning the meat it released from the pan with zero resistance and no residue left stuck on the pan surface. Removing the chicken, I added a tbsp more oil and in went the peppers and onion. Again, a gorgeous result. Nice searing and no sticking. Added the meat back, added sauce, and the same meal I had prepared the night before in my quality non-stick skillet actually looked far more appetizing. And it was delicious. I dare say, even better due to the increased Maillard reaction over standard non-stick pans. Clean up entailed a wet sponge and a gentle wipe and rinse and it was clean. Nothing stuck. No discoloration. Soap and water finish.After enjoying my meal, I just had to know if the pans were going to pass the test that would make them a keeper for me: the French Omelette test. So I heated up the 10" pan, scrambled and seasoned three eggs, and threw a knob of butter into the pan. Medium low heat was plenty enough to get the job done. I worked quickly, keeping the eggs moving to avoid forming large curds. Once nearly set, I began rolling. The egg came away from the pan without a single stick, and without even the need to add more butter to release it as I would in my regular non-stick pans. Perfect, soft, yellow (not browned), creamy French Omelette. Clean up was a non-event. Aside from a bit of butter there wasn\'t anything for the soap, water, and sponge to remove. This test sealed the deal for me.I have other decent pans: All-Clad D3 12" and 10" pans, and three non-stick Oxo 8", 10", and 12" pans (top rated by America\'s Test Kitchen). The All-Clads can work okay, but they were mostly a disappointment. They take too long to heat up, the heat dissipates quickly when food is added, and they have cold spots around the outside where there isn\'t direct flame. The Oxo pans are actually pretty great, but they have rubber handles which can\'t go into the oven, and even medium heat just isn\'t hot enough. Not the pan\'s fault, but you\'ll never get a sear on a non-stick surface. My goal here was to have ONE set of pans that could get proper searing, could be used in the oven, and still have non-stick properties. I have achieved that goal with the HexClad pans. My All-Clad and Oxo pans will be gifted to someone. I have no need for them anymore.Handles: Nice, fat handles on the HexClad that don\'t turn in your hands or get hot. The worst thing about the All-Clad D3\'s are the handles. I have nearly dumped the contents of both pans when tossing as the handles rotated in my palm. They are the absolute worst. I absolutely LOVE the HexClad handles.Lids: Every HexClad pan came with a nice, glass lid that fits perfectly, and has a steam vent. All-Clad? Because my D3 set didn\'t come with lids initially, All-Clad doesn\'t and won\'t sell them separately. I called All-Clad when I got them and asked if they\'d sell me some lids and they basically told me to go pound sand. They were actually rude and dismissive.Heat distribution: As mentioned, the All-Clad D3\'s didn\'t evenly distribute the heat to the outsides of the pan surface that weren\'t directly over flame, nor did they keep the heat when food was added. Even cranking the flame up to high was never enough to get a good sear. Not so with the HexClad. I was sure that the warning to not heat them above medium had something to do with the non-stick surface (and it might), but it\'s just not necessary to go any higher. The outsides of the pan are just as hot as the middle and they sear so well, keeping their heat even as food is added. They perform almost like carbon steel or cast iron in this regard.Non-stick: Covered this, but it bears repeating that these actually are non-stick when used properly.Appearance: They\'re gorgeous, aren\'t they? My friend\'s set has no discoloration after several months of daily, hard use, and he\'s never had to use Barkeeper\'s Friend or any scouring. They are absolutely stunning under the LED cook lights of my hood. Prettier by far than the All-Clad.I\'ve ordered the 2, 3, and 8 QT pot set, which arrives tomorrow, and expect to be equally happy if these pans are any indication. I also have a 10" wok arriving next week for my near daily stir fries. At some point, I may also add a 1 QT pot and 7 QT deep saute.The bottom line is that these pans aren\'t going to miraculously make you cook better. But they WILL reward good technique with superior results. I was skeptical coming into this that I wouldn\'t like them nearly as much as what I already had but any hesitation is gone. The hype is real with this tech.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 16, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars This was part of the 12-piece set I ordered', 'author': 'Judy L.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This was part of the 12 piece set I ordered that was shipped in 2 boxes.
